newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU formally agrees pact to end U.S. anti-Cuba row.
newsitem.headline: EU formally agrees pact to end U.S. anti-Cuba row.

text.p: European Union member countries formally agreed on Friday to a deal with the United States to end a transatlantic row over U.S. anti-Cuba legislation, a European Commission spokesman said.
The spokesman said all 15 EU countries had told Brussels they supported a plan that would end a disputes panel at the World Trade Organisation (WTO) over the so-called Helms-Burton act.
The act, an amalgam of U.S. anti-Cuba laws, has outraged Washington's trading partners because it threatens non-U.S. businesses with interests in Cuba.

The European Commission and Washington agreed last week to negotiate a compromise in policy towards Cuba under which the EU would drop its WTO complaint and work with the United States toward a global agreement on protection of expropriated property.
The White House would in exchange seek to change a key provision of Helms-Burton barring executives of companies that invest in disputed properties in Cuba from entering the United States.

On Wednesday, EU ambassadors provisionally backed the plan but added a sharply worded statement warning Washington not to renege on the deal. EU governments had until Friday to endorse the ambassadors' decision.
